articles.title: Choi, 17, denies Kim historic third halfpipe gold
articles.summary: Seventeen-year-old Choi Ga-on denies American great Chloe Kim snowboarding history as she brushes off an early fall to win Winter Olympic halfpipe gold.
articles.content:
It felt like the moment the baton was passed on.

Chloe Kim, the greatest women's halfpipe snowboarder, and Choi Ga-on, the young protege, standing side by side on the podium.

It was expected to be a procession for American Kim to win a third consecutive Winter Olympic gold, a feat no snowboarder has ever achieved. And yet it was 17-year-old Choi on the top step at the Milan-Cortina Games.

The South Korean had defied a brutal fall in her opening run to score 90.25 points on her final attempt, a total 25-year-old Kim could not better.

It was, as Kim told BBC Sport, a "full circle moment".

The two had met nine years ago, at a test event in Pyeongchang before the 2018 Games in which Kim, then also aged 17, would announce herself on a global stage with her first Olympic gold.

Realising her potential, Kim and her father helped Choi to travel to the United States to train.

Kim's father, who is from South Korea, was one of the first to embrace Choi and her emotional team after her Olympic gold was confirmed.

"She's someone I've known since she was little," said Kim.

"It's such a full circle moment seeing her from when she was so young to now standing next to her on the Olympic podium."
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant and inspiring sports achievement where a young athlete overcomes challenges to win Olympic gold, symbolizing mentorship, international friendship, and the passing of a legacy. This has broad inspirational impact beyond just sports fans, offering hope and emotional uplift.
articles.personality_title: 17-year-old Choi wins Olympic halfpipe gold, ending Chloe Kim’s streak
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Chloe Kim, an American snowboarder, had won two Olympic gold medals in the halfpipe event and was aiming for a historic third win at the Winter Olympics. Choi Ga-on, a 17-year-old from South Korea, trained in the United States and was seen as a rising star in the sport.

**What happened** – At the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics, Choi Ga-on fell early in her first run but made a strong comeback with a final score of 90.25 points. This score was higher than Chloe Kim’s, who is 25 years old, allowing Choi to win the gold medal in the halfpipe event.

**Impact** – This win is important because no snowboarder has ever won three Olympic golds in the halfpipe. Choi’s victory shows that a young athlete can rise quickly and challenge established champions. It also highlights a special friendship and mentorship between Chloe Kim and Choi, as Kim helped Choi train and grow in the sport.

**What's next step** – Choi’s win could inspire more young snowboarders, especially from South Korea, to compete at the highest level. Chloe Kim may continue to compete and try to win more medals, while both athletes represent a new generation of snowboarders shaping the sport.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A young South Korean snowboarder, Choi Ga-on, overcame an early fall to win Olympic gold, marking a new chapter in halfpipe snowboarding and celebrating a bond with her mentor Chloe Kim.

articles.title: Press release - President Metsola: “We have a narrow window to deliver for Europe and we must.”
articles.summary: Speaking at the Leaders’ retreat on competitiveness, President Metsola said that there was “a narrow window of opportunity” to do the necessary to push Europe forward. Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
“What the pandemic did for our response to health, and Ukraine did for our response to defence - now is the time to do for European competitiveness.”

In her speech to leaders, President Metsola made four points:

1/ Complete the Single Market

“Fragmentation means we are allowing ourselves to be squeezed from our East and our West. At the speed with which things are moving, we need to act - now.”

“If we can go forward together let’s do it, but we cannot be stuck. The way forward needs to be defined by pragmatic realism that delivers tangible results.”

2/ Keep cutting red tape

“Parliament has done a lot in the last year on simplification. We have eased requirements in the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, reduced red-tape in the Common Agricultural Policy and in InvestEU. We have narrowed the scope of the CSRD and CSDDD. (...) Regarding proposals to revise rules on digital, environmental, automotive and food sectors, work in committees is moving fast. Now we also need to see the examples of national rules that stunt growth. Ultimately, good intentions must translate into urgent tangible outcomes for businesses and families.”

3/ Reinforce public and private funding, especially in energy

“Our task is to find ways to inject more capital into high potential sectors without causing instability and weighing down our budgets. Europe does not suffer from a lack of savings. It suffers from a lack of turning those savings into investment.”

President Metsola stressed the urgency of investing in grids and generation capacity to “build a genuine Energy Union - one that guarantees stable supply for our industries, at affordable prices for our people. As we enter the Age of Electricity - investment in energy supply and delivery is crucial. Energy is the new gold and the global rush for it is the same.”

4/ Pursue an ambitious free trade agenda with partners and allies around the world

“The trade agreement with India was exactly the right message, the right tone, and the right deal. We know that strategic autonomy is not about isolation - it is about influence. “

“Where possible we should buy European. But where not, we shouldn’t sacrifice our industries that depend on external resources under the illusion of self-reliance. Openness must remain at the core of our European model.”

“In this spirit, Parliament cleared the agricultural safeguards for the EU-Mercosur agreement. Now we are finalising our work on the EU-US trade agreement. The vote in committee will take place on the 24th, then we’ll go to plenary in March. We recognise the urgency to get this trade deal done - just as we recognise the need for it to be grounded in mutual trust, understanding and respect. Open, but never naive.”

articles.personality_title: President Metsola calls for urgent action to boost Europe’s economy and energy security
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Europe faces challenges from global competition and changing markets. President Metsola spoke at a meeting focused on how to improve Europe’s ability to compete and grow economically.

**What happened** – At the Leaders’ retreat on competitiveness, President Metsola outlined four main steps to strengthen Europe. She urged completing the Single Market to reduce divisions, cutting unnecessary rules that slow businesses, increasing investment in energy to ensure stable and affordable supply, and pushing for strong free trade deals with countries like India and the US.

**Impact** – These plans aim to make Europe faster and stronger in facing economic challenges. By improving trade and energy systems, Europe hopes to protect jobs, keep prices stable, and support businesses. The focus on real, practical changes means these ideas could quickly help families and companies.

**What’s next step** – The European Parliament will continue working on trade agreements, with important votes planned soon. Investments in energy infrastructure are expected to grow. Leaders will need to agree on how to finish the Single Market and reduce rules that hold back growth.

**One-sentence takeaway** – President Metsola’s clear plan focuses on teamwork, investment, and smart trade to make Europe’s economy more competitive and secure in a fast-changing world.
articles.personality_title_fr: La présidente Metsola appelle à une action urgente pour renforcer l’économie et la sécurité énergétique de l’Europe
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Europe fait face à des défis liés à la concurrence mondiale et aux marchés en évolution. La présidente Metsola s’est exprimée lors d’une réunion consacrée à l’amélioration de la compétitivité et de la croissance économique européenne.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors du sommet sur la compétitivité, la présidente Metsola a présenté quatre mesures principales pour renforcer l’Europe. Elle a demandé de compléter le marché unique pour réduire les divisions, de supprimer les règles inutiles qui freinent les entreprises, d’augmenter les investissements dans l’énergie pour garantir un approvisionnement stable et abordable, et de promouvoir des accords commerciaux solides avec des pays comme l’Inde et les États-Unis.

**Impact** – Ces mesures visent à rendre l’Europe plus rapide et plus forte face aux défis économiques. En améliorant le commerce et les systèmes énergétiques, l’Europe espère protéger les emplois, stabiliser les prix et soutenir les entreprises. L’accent mis sur des changements pratiques signifie que ces idées pourraient rapidement bénéficier aux familles et aux entreprises.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Parlement européen poursuivra le travail sur les accords commerciaux, avec des votes importants à venir. Les investissements dans les infrastructures énergétiques devraient augmenter. Les dirigeants devront s’accorder sur la finalisation du marché unique et la réduction des règles qui freinent la croissance.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le plan clair de la présidente Metsola mise sur la coopération, l’investissement et un commerce intelligent pour rendre l’économie européenne plus compétitive et sécurisée dans un monde en évolution rapide.
articles.personality_title_es: La presidenta Metsola pide acción urgente para fortalecer la economía y seguridad energética de Europa
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Europa enfrenta desafíos por la competencia global y mercados cambiantes. La presidenta Metsola habló en una reunión enfocada en cómo mejorar la capacidad de Europa para competir y crecer económicamente.

**Qué pasó** – En la cumbre sobre competitividad, la presidenta Metsola presentó cuatro pasos clave para fortalecer Europa. Instó a completar el Mercado Único para reducir divisiones, eliminar reglas innecesarias que frenan a las empresas, aumentar la inversión en energía para asegurar un suministro estable y asequible, y promover acuerdos comerciales fuertes con países como India y Estados Unidos.

**Impacto** – Estos planes buscan hacer a Europa más rápida y fuerte frente a los desafíos económicos. Al mejorar el comercio y los sistemas energéticos, Europa espera proteger empleos, mantener precios estables y apoyar a las empresas. El enfoque en cambios prácticos significa que estas ideas podrían ayudar pronto a familias y negocios.

**Próximo paso** – El Parlamento Europeo continuará trabajando en acuerdos comerciales, con votaciones importantes próximamente. Se espera que crezcan las inversiones en infraestructura energética. Los líderes deberán acordar cómo completar el Mercado Único y reducir reglas que frenan el crecimiento.

**Resumen en una frase** – El plan claro de la presidenta Metsola se basa en el trabajo en equipo, la inversión y el comercio inteligente para hacer que la economía europea sea más competitiva y segura en un mundo que cambia rápido.
